Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English, I'm Neil
And I'm Rob
speaker: Neil

text: We're going to be looking at a letter from the English alphabet.
speaker: Neil

text: It's a letter which has a particular meaning
when used at the end of a piece of informal writing,
such as letters, emails, texts and messages.
Oh, I'm very excited.
Yeah, very good, very good, Rob.
My expectations are really high.
speaker: Neil

text: Yep, that's another good one.
speaker: Neil

text: Is it an extraordinary letter?
Okay, thank you, Rob.
That's enough of your jokes.
speaker: Neil

text: I'm getting exasperated.
Now you've got me at it.
Well, no prizes for guessing what letter we're focusing on today.
Why?
speaker: Neil

text: No, it's not why.
No, no, I didn't mean the letter why.
I meant the word why,
as in, why are there no prizes?
Because of all the not so subtle clues you’ve been giving.
speaker: Neil

text: the letter is excess, exactly.
All right, I think we get the idea.
Before we go much further, let's have a question.
speaker: Neil

text: English has 26 letters.
speaker: dockedquiddockquid

text: Which language has 74 letters?
Is it A, Camille?
b) Hindi or c) Armenian
speaker: Neil

text: Any ideas Rob?
speaker: Neil

text: An excellent question, but quite obscure.
I'm going to say B, Hindi.
Well, I'll have the answer later on.
speaker: Neil

text: Now, Rob, what does the letter X all by itself
at the end of a message mean?
Well, it means a kiss.
The more kisses, the more affection you are showing.
Where does this concept of putting an X to mean a kiss come from?
speaker: Neil

text: Dr. Laura Wright is from the Faculty of English at Cambridge University
and she appeared on the BBC Radio 4 program, Word of Mouth.
When does she say this practice started and where does it come from?
Well, we've been adding X's for kisses at the bottom of our letter
since at least 1763.
speaker: Neil

text: So the very first one we know of had seven X's.
I have to say I haven't gone to seven ever.
speaker: Neil

text: Probably.
We get X from the Roman alphabet, which got it from the Greek alphabet,
pronounced X.
And the Romans certainly found it good for cars.
It's nearly a kiss, isn't it?
Yeah, it is, isn't it?
I think a penny's just dropped there.
speaker: Dr Laura Wright, Faculty of English, University of Cambridge

text: It has, clunk.
speaker: a penny’s just dropped

text: What did we learn about the origins of the X for kisses?
Well, it's been used since at least 1763
and it comes from the Roman alphabet and they got it from the Greeks.
And why did this come to mean a kiss?
speaker: Neil

text: Well, Dr. Wright suggests it's because of the original pronunciation.
And at that point, the presenter made the connection, didn't he?
Yes, he did.
speaker: Neil

text: And Dr. Wright used a phrase for when someone suddenly understands something,
particularly something that is obvious to others.
She said the penny has just dropped.
And this has got nothing to do with a penny,
speaker: pennyclunk

text: which is a small coin actually dropping anywhere.
But the presenter makes a joke by using a word we use for the noise of something falling.
Clunk.
speaker: the penny has dropped

text: Although, to be honest, a penny would never really clunk.
That's more like the noise to heavy metal objects would make.
The clunk of a car door, for example.
Let's listen to that exchange again.
Well, we've been adding X's for kisses at the bottom of our letter
since at least 1763.
So the very first one we know of had seven X's.
I have to say I haven't gone to seven ever.
We get X from the Roman alphabet, which got it from the Greek alphabet, pronounced X.
And the Romans certainly found it good for cars.
That's nearly a kiss, isn't it?
Yeah, it is, isn't it?
I think the penny has just dropped there.
It has. Clunk.
One thing to note about putting an X at the end of a communication is that it is not something
speaker: Neil

text: you do for everyone.
It's usually only to friends and family members, people you might kiss in real life.
Professor Nils Langer from the University of Bristol told a story about a colleague of his
who wasn't too familiar with this convention. What was her mistake?
I've got a colleague of mine at Bristol who, when she came over from Germany,
thought that X is just the normal way of closing a letter in England.
And so she wouldn't finish any letter with the X's, even letter to the England revenue.
We never heard really how the England revenue responded to this letter with these X's.
But...
speaker: Inland Revenue

text: Hmm, they doctor another 20 quid, I think.
What was her mistake, Rob?
speaker: dockedquid

text: She didn't realise that you don't put an X on every communication.
She even put it on a business letter, including one to the inland revenue,
which is the government department in the UK, that deals with tax.
We don't know how the tax people felt about the letter with kisses,
but the presenter joked about what their response would have been.
Yes, he joked that they probably doctor another 20 quid.
To dock money is to cut the amount of money you're expecting to receive.
An a quid is a slang word for a British pound.
Now time for the answer to our question.
English has 26 letters, but which language has 74 letters?
Is it a, Cmere, B, Hindi or C, Armenian?
I guessed B, Hindi.
speaker: Neil

text: Well, I suppose it was a one-in-three chance, but not correct this time.
The answer is A, Cmere.
Very well done if you knew that.
speaker: Neil

text: Now on to the vocabulary we looked at in this programme.
Hmm, we started with a penny.
A penny is an English coin.
A hundred pennies makes one pound sterling.
The phrase the penny has dropped means that someone has suddenly understood something.
A clunk is the noise of two heavy objects hitting each other.
The Inland Revenue is the UK’s tax authority.
speaker: Inland Revenue

text: And if you dock money from someone, you reduce the amount of money you pay them.
For example, as an employee in the UK, your tax is automatically docked from your salary.
And finally, a quid, which is a slang term for one pound sterling
speaker: a quiddocking

text: Right, before they start docking our pay for being late, it's time to say goodbye.
